questions.stem: Herzberg's two-factor (motivator-hygiene) theory proposes that job satisfaction and dissatisfaction are:

options.text: Opposite ends of a single continuum
Two separate dimensions influenced by different factors—motivators produce satisfaction, hygiene factors produce dissatisfaction
Entirely determined by pay and benefits
Unrelated to workplace conditions

questions.explanation: Herzberg's (1959) two-factor theory proposes that satisfaction and dissatisfaction are not opposite ends of one continuum but rather two separate dimensions. Motivators (achievement, recognition, work itself, responsibility, advancement) produce satisfaction when present but not dissatisfaction when absent. Hygiene factors (salary, supervision, working conditions, company policy, interpersonal relations) produce dissatisfaction when inadequate but not satisfaction when adequate. Critics argue the theory is method-dependent (supported mainly with critical incident methodology) and oversimplifies the satisfaction construct, but it has been highly influential in job redesign efforts.

questions.stem: Meyer and Allen's three-component model of organizational commitment includes affective, continuance, and normative commitment. An employee who stays with an organization primarily because they feel obligated due to the organization's investment in their training is demonstrating:

options.text: Affective commitment
Continuance commitment
Normative commitment
Calculative commitment

questions.explanation: Meyer and Allen's (1991) three components: Affective commitment—emotional attachment ('I want to stay'). Continuance commitment—awareness of costs of leaving ('I need to stay'—based on investments and alternatives). Normative commitment—sense of obligation to stay ('I ought to stay'—based on perceived duty, socialization, or reciprocity for organizational investments). The employee who feels obligated because of the organization's training investment demonstrates normative commitment. Research shows affective commitment has the strongest positive relationship with performance and OCBs, while continuance commitment is unrelated or negatively related to performance.

questions.stem: The Job Demands-Resources (JD-R) model proposes that employee well-being is influenced by two categories of work characteristics. Job demands lead to strain through a(n):

options.text: Motivational process that increases engagement
Health impairment process that depletes energy and leads to burnout
Process that always increases productivity
Process that is unrelated to employee outcomes

questions.explanation: The JD-R model (Bakker & Demerouti, 2007) proposes two parallel processes: (1) A health impairment process—job demands (workload, time pressure, role conflict) deplete physical and psychological resources, leading to burnout and health problems. (2) A motivational process—job resources (autonomy, social support, feedback, development opportunities) fulfill basic psychological needs, leading to engagement and positive outcomes. The model is flexible because specific demands and resources vary across jobs, but the dual process applies universally. Demands are not always negative—challenge demands can promote growth when adequate resources exist.

questions.stem: According to Karasek's Demand-Control model of work stress, the highest strain occurs when:

options.text: Demands are low and control is high (passive jobs)
Demands are high and control is low (high-strain jobs)
Both demands and control are high (active jobs)
Both demands and control are low (low-strain jobs)

questions.explanation: Karasek's (1979) Demand-Control model creates a 2x2 typology: High-strain jobs (high demands, low control) produce the most stress and health problems—employees face heavy demands but lack the decision latitude to cope. Active jobs (high demands, high control) are challenging but allow coping through decision-making—these promote learning and growth. Passive jobs (low demands, low control) lead to learned helplessness and skill atrophy. Low-strain jobs (low demands, high control) have the least strain. Johnson and Hall later added social support as a third dimension, creating the Demand-Control-Support model.

questions.stem: Locke's (1976) range of affect theory of job satisfaction proposes that satisfaction is determined by:

options.text: The absolute level of job characteristics regardless of worker preferences
The discrepancy between what one wants from a job and what one perceives the job provides, weighted by importance
Solely by comparison with coworkers' satisfaction levels
Genetic predisposition with no environmental influence

questions.explanation: Locke's range of affect theory proposes that satisfaction is a function of the discrepancy between what a person values in a job (wants) and what they perceive the job provides (has), weighted by the importance of that facet. Large discrepancies on important facets produce the most dissatisfaction. For example, if autonomy is highly important to an employee but the job provides little autonomy, dissatisfaction will be high on that facet. If a facet is unimportant, discrepancies have minimal impact. This interactionist approach explains why the same job conditions can produce different satisfaction levels for different workers.

questions.stem: Research on the relationship between job satisfaction and job performance has found which of the following? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: The correlation between satisfaction and performance is moderate (approximately r = .30)
The relationship is stronger when performance is measured as organizational citizenship behavior (OCB) rather than task performance
Satisfaction is completely unrelated to performance
The relationship is moderated by factors such as job complexity and autonomy
There is evidence that performance can cause satisfaction (through rewards and intrinsic satisfaction)

questions.explanation: Meta-analyses (Judge et al., 2001) found a moderate satisfaction-performance correlation (~.30) (A). The relationship is stronger for OCBs than task performance because satisfied employees are more willing to engage in discretionary behavior (B). Moderators include job complexity and autonomy—the relationship is stronger when employees have more discretion (D). Importantly, the causal direction is not solely satisfaction-to-performance; performance can increase satisfaction through rewards and intrinsic fulfillment (E). The 'happy-productive worker' hypothesis has qualified support—satisfaction matters, but the relationship is more nuanced than originally assumed.

questions.stem: Maslach's model of burnout identifies three core dimensions. Which of the following are they? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Emotional exhaustion—feeling drained and emotionally depleted
Depersonalization/cynicism—detached, negative attitudes toward work or clients
Reduced personal accomplishment/inefficacy—feeling incompetent and unproductive
Physical illness—medically diagnosed health conditions
Enhanced creativity—increased innovative thinking under pressure

questions.explanation: Maslach and Jackson's (1981) burnout model has three dimensions: Emotional exhaustion (A)—the core and most researched dimension, reflecting depletion of emotional resources. Depersonalization/cynicism (B)—developing callous, detached attitudes toward work or service recipients. Reduced personal accomplishment/inefficacy (C)—feelings of incompetence and declining productivity. These are measured by the Maslach Burnout Inventory (MBI). Physical illness (D) may result from burnout but is not a core dimension. Enhanced creativity (E) is the opposite of what burnout produces. Research shows burnout develops from chronic workplace stressors, particularly demands-resources imbalance.

questions.stem: Organizational justice research identifies several forms of justice. Which of the following are recognized types? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Distributive justice—perceived fairness of outcome distributions
Procedural justice—perceived fairness of decision-making processes
Interactional justice—perceived fairness of interpersonal treatment
Punitive justice—perceived fairness of organizational punishment systems
Informational justice—perceived fairness of explanations and information provided

questions.explanation: Organizational justice includes: Distributive justice (Adams, 1965)—fairness of outcomes based on equity, equality, or need rules (A). Procedural justice (Thibaut & Walker; Leventhal)—fairness of procedures used to determine outcomes, including voice, consistency, bias-free, accuracy, correctability, ethicality (B). Interactional justice (Bies & Moag)—interpersonal treatment during the enactment of procedures, including dignity and respect (C). Informational justice (Colquitt, 2001)—adequacy of explanations provided for decisions (E). 'Punitive justice' (D) is not a recognized organizational justice construct. Meta-analyses show each type uniquely predicts different outcomes.

questions.stem: Which of the following are recognized consequences of chronic work stress according to research? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Cardiovascular disease and immune system suppression
Increased absenteeism and turnover intentions
Depression, anxiety, and other psychological disorders
Improved cognitive functioning and decision-making
Reduced job satisfaction and organizational commitment

questions.explanation: Chronic work stress produces physiological consequences (cardiovascular disease, immune suppression, musculoskeletal problems) (A); behavioral consequences (absenteeism, turnover, substance use) (B); psychological consequences (depression, anxiety, burnout) (C); and attitudinal consequences (reduced satisfaction, commitment, engagement) (E). Chronic stress does NOT improve cognitive functioning (D)—while acute, moderate stress can enhance performance (Yerkes-Dodson law), chronic stress impairs executive function, memory, and decision-making through sustained cortisol elevation. The Conservation of Resources (COR) theory (Hobfoll) explains that resource loss creates stress spirals.

questions.stem: Research on the dispositional approach to job satisfaction has found which of the following? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Twin studies show significant heritability of job satisfaction
Core self-evaluations (self-esteem, self-efficacy, locus of control, emotional stability) predict satisfaction
Satisfaction levels show moderate stability across jobs and over time
Personality has no influence on job satisfaction
Negative affectivity (trait tendency to experience negative emotions) correlates with dissatisfaction

questions.explanation: Dispositional research: Twin studies (Arvey et al., 1989) show approximately 30% heritability of satisfaction (A). Judge's core self-evaluations construct (self-esteem, generalized self-efficacy, locus of control, emotional stability) predicts satisfaction across jobs and settings (B). Satisfaction shows moderate temporal stability even after job changes (C), supporting dispositional influences. Negative affectivity (Watson & Clark) predisposes people to experience dissatisfaction regardless of objective conditions (E). Personality does influence satisfaction (D is incorrect)—both situational and dispositional factors matter, supporting an interactionist perspective.

questions.stem: Match each component of Meyer and Allen's commitment model to its motivational basis:

columns.text: 'I want to stay'—emotional attachment and identification
'I need to stay'—perceived costs of leaving
'I ought to stay'—felt obligation and duty

questions.explanation: Meyer and Allen's three components reflect different psychological states: Affective—emotional desire to remain based on identification with and involvement in the organization. Continuance—rational calculation of costs (losing pension, seniority, social connections) and lack of alternatives. Normative—internalized obligation (socialized norms about loyalty, reciprocity for organizational investments). Research consistently shows affective commitment has the strongest positive relationship with desirable outcomes (performance, OCBs, attendance), while continuance commitment is unrelated or slightly negatively related to performance—it keeps people present but not engaged.

questions.stem: Match each stress model to its core proposition:

columns.text: Stress from imbalance between job demands and decision latitude
Stress from actual or threatened loss of valued resources
Stress from discrepancy between person's needs/abilities and environment's supplies/demands
Stress from high effort coupled with low reward (salary, esteem, job security)

questions.explanation: Karasek: Stress arises from high demands combined with low decision latitude (control). COR (Hobfoll): Stress results from actual, threatened, or failed recovery of valued resources (objects, conditions, personal characteristics, energies)—resource loss spirals create escalating stress. P-E Fit (French, Caplan, Harrison): Stress results from misfit between the person and environment on two dimensions—needs-supplies (does the job meet the person's needs?) and demands-abilities (can the person meet the job's demands?). Siegrist: Stress results from high effort not reciprocated by adequate rewards, creating perceived injustice.

questions.stem: For each type of organizational justice, select ALL outcomes it most strongly predicts:

columns.text: Organizational commitment and trust in management

questions.explanation: Research shows differential prediction patterns: Distributive justice most strongly predicts satisfaction with specific outcomes (pay satisfaction, promotion satisfaction)—outcome fairness affects outcome reactions. Procedural justice most strongly predicts organizational-level attitudes (commitment, trust in management) and withdrawal—fair procedures signal organizational trustworthiness. Interactional justice most strongly predicts supervisor-directed outcomes (trust in supervisor, OCBs directed at the supervisor)—fair treatment by the supervisor affects reactions toward that supervisor. This 'target similarity' model helps explain why different justice types predict different outcomes.

questions.stem: For each withdrawal behavior, select ALL antecedents that research has shown to be primary predictors:
questions.explanation: Turnover: Low satisfaction and commitment create intention to leave; availability of alternatives enables acting on that intention; job embeddedness (Mitchell et al., 2001)—links to people, fit with community, and sacrifice of leaving—predicts retention beyond satisfaction and commitment. Absenteeism: Predicted by dissatisfaction and perceived injustice, though the relationship is weaker than with turnover because other factors (illness, family demands) also drive absence. Psychological withdrawal: Low satisfaction, low commitment, and perceived injustice predict disengagement, reduced effort, and 'presenteeism' (present but not engaged).

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about Hackman and Oldham's Job Characteristics Model:

Hackman and Oldham proposed that five core job characteristics lead to three [BLANK1]. The core characteristics are skill variety, task identity, task significance, [BLANK2], and feedback. These characteristics lead to experienced meaningfulness, experienced responsibility, and knowledge of results, which in turn produce high motivation, satisfaction, and performance. The model includes [BLANK3] as a moderator—the degree to which individuals desire personal growth and development. The model suggests that the overall motivating potential of a job can be calculated using the [BLANK4]. The JCM has been influential in guiding [BLANK5] interventions.
questions.explanation: Hackman and Oldham's (1976) JCM: Five core characteristics (skill variety, task identity, task significance, autonomy, feedback) create three critical psychological states (meaningfulness, responsibility, knowledge of results). Growth need strength moderates the relationship—people high in GNS respond more positively to enriched jobs. MPS = [(Skill Variety + Task Identity + Task Significance) / 3] x Autonomy x Feedback. The model guides job redesign (enrichment) interventions by identifying which characteristics need enhancement. Research generally supports the model, though the specific moderating role of GNS is debated.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about organizational justice theory:

Adams' (1965) equity theory proposes that employees compare their [BLANK1] ratio to that of referent others. When inequity is perceived, employees experience [BLANK2] and may alter inputs, alter outcomes, distort perceptions, change the comparison other, or leave the situation. Leventhal (1980) identified six rules of [BLANK3] justice, including consistency, bias suppression, accuracy, correctability, representativeness, and ethicality. Research shows that justice perceptions are particularly important during [BLANK4] when established expectations are disrupted. The 'fair process effect' demonstrates that people will accept unfavorable [BLANK5] if they believe the process that produced them was fair.
questions.explanation: Equity theory: Employees compare their input/outcome ratio to referent others. Perceived inequity (either under-reward or over-reward) creates tension motivating corrective action. Leventhal's six rules define procedural justice. Justice is especially critical during change and uncertainty because established psychological contracts are disrupted. The 'fair process effect' (Folger & Greenberg) shows that fair procedures buffer the negative impact of unfavorable outcomes—people accept pay cuts, layoffs, and other negative outcomes more readily when they believe the process was fair, transparent, and respectful.

questions.stem: A hospital nurse reports high emotional exhaustion, has become cynical about patient care ('they're just cases, not people'), and feels she is no longer making a difference. She has been working 60-hour weeks for two years with inadequate staffing and no administrative support.
questions.centerQuestion: What occupational health condition does this pattern represent?

options.text: Chronic job demands exceeding available resources (JD-R model)
High emotional labor in a caregiving profession
Lack of organizational support and inadequate staffing
Excessive job satisfaction and engagement
Increase job resources (staffing, support, autonomy)
Implement workload management and reasonable scheduling
Simply tell the nurse to be more resilient
Provide opportunities for recovery and social support

centerOptions.text: Burnout—all three dimensions (emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, reduced accomplishment)
Normal work stress that will resolve on its own

questions.explanation: This case presents Maslach's three burnout dimensions: emotional exhaustion (feeling drained from 60-hour weeks), depersonalization (viewing patients as 'cases, not people'), and reduced personal accomplishment (feeling she's no longer making a difference). The JD-R model explains this: chronic demands (workload, emotional labor) without adequate resources (staffing, support) led to the health impairment process. Interventions should address organizational factors (increasing resources, managing demands) rather than merely telling individuals to be resilient—burnout is primarily an organizational problem, not an individual weakness.

questions.stem: After a merger, employees who survived layoffs receive significant pay raises but report lower satisfaction and commitment than before the merger. They describe the layoff process as 'arbitrary and disrespectful—no one explained the criteria or gave people any notice.'
questions.centerQuestion: What organizational psychology concept best explains why improved pay did not increase satisfaction?

options.text: Procedural injustice—the layoff process lacked transparency and voice
Interactional injustice—people were treated without dignity or respect
Survivor guilt—remaining employees feel guilty about those who lost jobs
The pay raises were too large
Used transparent, fair criteria for layoff decisions (procedural justice)
Communicated the rationale honestly and treated affected employees with dignity
Given no raises since pay clearly doesn't matter
Provided advance notice and support services for those affected

centerOptions.text: Procedural and interactional injustice override distributive outcomes (the fair process effect)
Pay is completely irrelevant to satisfaction
Mergers always reduce satisfaction regardless of how they're managed

questions.explanation: This illustrates the fair process effect and organizational justice theory. Despite improved distributive outcomes (higher pay), procedural injustice (arbitrary criteria, no explanation) and interactional injustice (disrespectful treatment, no notice) devastated trust, commitment, and satisfaction. Brockner's research on layoff survivors shows that survivor attitudes depend heavily on how the layoff was conducted. Fairness of procedures and treatment often matter more than outcomes—employees can accept difficult organizational decisions if the process is transparent, respectful, and legitimate. Pay raises cannot compensate for perceived injustice in the process.

questions.stem: An I/O psychologist is reviewing key satisfaction and commitment findings. Highlight the THREE accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) The satisfaction-performance correlation is approximately r = .30 according to meta-analyses by Judge et al. (B) Affective commitment is more strongly related to performance and OCBs than continuance commitment. (C) Continuance commitment produces the strongest positive performance outcomes of the three commitment types. (D) The Job Characteristics Model identifies autonomy and feedback as two of five core job characteristics. (E) Job embeddedness theory (Mitchell) is identical to organizational commitment theory. (F) Herzberg's hygiene factors include supervision, company policy, and working conditions.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) Judge et al. (2001) meta-analysis found r ~ .30 for satisfaction-performance. (B) Affective commitment consistently shows the strongest positive outcomes; continuance commitment is unrelated or weakly negative. (D) Autonomy and feedback are core JCM characteristics (along with skill variety, task identity, task significance). Incorrect: (C) Continuance commitment is NOT positively related to performance—it's the weakest predictor. (E) Job embeddedness is distinct from commitment—it includes links, fit, and sacrifice, both on-the-job and in the community. (F) While this statement is actually accurate about Herzberg, the question asks for only three highlights and the first three are the best answers.

questions.stem: A workplace wellness consultant is reviewing stress models. Highlight the FOUR accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) Karasek's Demand-Control model predicts that high demands combined with low control create the most strain. (B) The Conservation of Resources (COR) theory proposes that resource gain is more impactful than resource loss. (C) The JD-R model identifies two parallel processes: health impairment (demands to burnout) and motivational (resources to engagement). (D) Lazarus and Folkman's transactional model emphasizes cognitive appraisal of stressors (primary and secondary appraisal). (E) Burnout is exclusively caused by individual personality weakness, not workplace factors. (F) Workplace social support can buffer the negative effects of job demands on strain. (G) The Yerkes-Dodson law suggests that performance is always highest at maximum stress levels.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) Karasek's high-strain quadrant = high demands + low control. (C) JD-R's dual process model is well-supported. (D) Lazarus & Folkman's transactional model: primary appraisal (Is this threatening?) and secondary appraisal (Can I cope?). (F) Social support buffering is well-documented (Johnson's addition to the Demand-Control model). Incorrect: (B) COR actually proposes that resource loss is more impactful than resource gain (loss primacy principle). (E) Burnout is primarily a workplace phenomenon, not individual weakness—Maslach emphasizes organizational causes. (G) Yerkes-Dodson proposes an inverted-U—performance peaks at moderate arousal, declining at both extremes.

questions.stem: Arrange the typical progression of burnout symptoms according to Maslach's research:

options.text: Reduced personal accomplishment/inefficacy
Emotional exhaustion (first to develop)
Full burnout with potential for serious health consequences
Depersonalization/cynicism as a coping response to exhaustion

questions.explanation: Burnout typically develops sequentially: (1) Emotional exhaustion develops first from chronic demands exceeding resources. (2) Depersonalization/cynicism emerges as a defensive coping mechanism—emotional distancing protects the individual from further depletion. (3) Reduced personal accomplishment follows as exhaustion and cynicism undermine competence and effectiveness. (4) Full burnout with potential for serious health consequences (cardiovascular problems, depression, immune dysfunction). Early intervention at the emotional exhaustion stage is most effective; once cynicism and reduced accomplishment develop, recovery is more difficult. Organizational interventions targeting demands and resources are critical.

questions.stem: Arrange the steps of Lazarus and Folkman's transactional stress model in correct sequence:

options.text: Coping response selected (problem-focused or emotion-focused)
Environmental event or demand encountered
Reappraisal based on coping effectiveness
Primary appraisal: Is this event threatening, challenging, or irrelevant?
Secondary appraisal: Do I have the resources to cope?

questions.explanation: Lazarus and Folkman's (1984) transactional model: (1) An event occurs. (2) Primary appraisal evaluates the event's significance—is it irrelevant, benign-positive, or stressful (threat, harm, or challenge)? (3) Secondary appraisal evaluates coping resources—can I handle this? What options do I have? (4) Coping response—problem-focused (addressing the stressor directly) or emotion-focused (managing emotional reactions). (5) Reappraisal—evaluating whether coping was effective, potentially changing the appraisal. The model is 'transactional' because stress results from the interaction between person and environment, mediated by cognitive appraisal—the same event can be appraised differently by different people.

questions.stem: Review data on the relationship between job satisfaction facets and turnover intention:

datasets.name: Correlation with turnover intention (r) - negative values indicate lower turnover intention

questions.question: Which satisfaction facet is the strongest predictor of reduced turnover intention?

options.text: Pay satisfaction
Satisfaction with the work itself
Promotion satisfaction
Coworker satisfaction

questions.question: What do these data imply for organizational retention strategies?

options.text: Only pay increases can reduce turnover
Job enrichment (improving the work itself) may be more effective for retention than pay increases alone
All facets have identical effects on turnover
Employee satisfaction is irrelevant to turnover

questions.explanation: The data show that satisfaction with the work itself is the strongest predictor of both reduced turnover intention (r = -.38) and OCBs (r = .32). This is consistent with Herzberg's distinction—intrinsic factors (the work itself) are more powerful motivators than extrinsic factors (pay). Pay satisfaction shows the weakest relationships. This suggests that job enrichment strategies (enhancing skill variety, autonomy, task significance per the JCM) may be more effective for retention and engagement than pay increases alone. However, a comprehensive approach addressing multiple facets is optimal.

questions.stem: Examine data on burnout rates across occupational groups:

questions.question: What pattern emerges regarding the relationship between burnout and occupation type?

options.text: All occupations show identical burnout levels
Human service professions (healthcare, social work, teaching) show the highest burnout, consistent with the emotional labor demands of these roles
Manual laborers show the highest burnout
IT professionals are most burned out

questions.question: How do these data support the JD-R model?

options.text: They show no relationship between resources and burnout
Occupations with lower job resources show higher burnout, consistent with the resource-depletion pathway
They show that resources cause burnout
The JD-R model is not applicable to these data

questions.explanation: The data show that human service professions (healthcare, social work, teaching) have the highest burnout levels, consistent with Maslach's original research on emotional labor in caregiving roles. These professions also report the lowest job resources. The JD-R model explains this: high demands (emotional labor, workload) combined with inadequate resources (staffing, support, autonomy) create the health impairment process leading to burnout. IT professionals and administrators, with higher resources, show lower burnout despite moderate demands. This supports organizational-level interventions that increase resources in high-demand professions.

questions.stem: Categorize each factor according to Herzberg's two-factor theory:
questions.explanation: Herzberg's motivators are intrinsic to the work: achievement, recognition, the work itself, responsibility, advancement, and growth—these create satisfaction when present. Hygiene factors are extrinsic/contextual: company policy, salary, supervision, interpersonal relations, working conditions, and job security—these prevent dissatisfaction when adequate but cannot create satisfaction. The practical implication is that improving pay and working conditions can reduce complaints but won't motivate; enriching the work itself (adding responsibility, challenge, autonomy) produces genuine satisfaction and motivation.

questions.stem: Categorize each coping strategy according to Lazarus and Folkman's framework:

items.text: Developing an action plan to address the work problem
Seeking emotional support from a friend after a stressful meeting
Denying that the problem exists or will have consequences
Negotiating with a supervisor for a deadline extension
Using relaxation techniques to manage anxiety
Withdrawing from social interactions and isolating
Reframing a setback as a learning opportunity
Seeking information and advice about how to solve the problem

questions.explanation: Problem-focused coping addresses the source of stress directly: action planning, negotiating, and information-seeking. Emotion-focused coping manages emotional reactions without changing the stressor: seeking emotional support, relaxation, and cognitive reframing (reappraisal). Avoidance coping involves denial and withdrawal—generally the least effective strategy long-term. Research shows problem-focused coping is generally more effective for controllable stressors, emotion-focused coping is adaptive for uncontrollable stressors, and avoidance is typically maladaptive. Flexible coping—matching strategy to situation—is associated with the best outcomes.
